SECOND COUNT, for stealing four promissory notes for payment of 5l. each, value 20l., the property of
John Winskill
.

MARGARET WINSKILL
. I am the wife of John Winskill, who keeps the White Hart public-house, Giltspur-street - the prisoner was in his service nearly three months, and was intrusted to take money. On Saturday, the 10th of February, I sent him with four 5l. Huntingdon notes, to go to Esdaile's to change them, and go to the Bank and get silver for them - he went about ten o'clock, and I directed him to be back by twelve o'clock - he said he should have plenty of time to return, but he never did return. My husband brought him back on the Saturday fortnight, and he was taken to the Compter - he never returned any thing that he got for these four notes.

JOHN WINSKILL. I was not at home when my wife delivered these notes to the prisoner; but I endeavoured to find out where he came from, and I found, by a letter, that his father lived at Harlstonham - I went there, and found him at Yarmouth - he said he was very sorry for what he had done; I found on him three sovereigns, and 14s. in the bag which his mistress gave him for the money - he had purchased a great coat for 3l. 10s., a hat, and a cloak, and taken a cloak out of pawn, and paid his expenses on the road; he said the money I found on him was all he had left - I had a character with him from Mr. Williams, of Aldersgate-street.

GEORGE HASLEWOOD WORRALL
. I am an officer of St. Sepulchre's. I received the prisoner into custody at Mr. Winskill's house. I have the watch and great coat - he told Mr. Winskill this money was all he had left.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1011.
JOHN MURRAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of February , 30 lbs. weight of iron, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
George Turner
and
Charlotte Turner
.

WILLIAM HOWARD TURNER
. I am brother to George Turner and Charlotte Turner; they are in partnership, as pump and engine manufacturers
- the prisoner was quite a stranger - I know nothing of this matter.

WILLIAM COLTON
. I am a constable. On the 25th of February I saw the prisoner, and another young man, with him, near Red Lion-street, Holborn, about seven o'clock in the evening; it was quite dark; I followed him nearly a mile to Mr. Turner's factory, near the Temple, in Whitefriars; I saw the prisoner get over a high iron railing, andhand something over, but I could not see what it was, as it was dark; I know there was a great quantity of iron pipes for pumps, deposited there; they then went up a court by the side of the glass-house, which led them round to Water-lane. I followed them, but lost sight of them in a court; I then met them again in Shoe-lane (I had taken sufficient notice of them to know they were the same persons); when they got to the end of Shoe-lane the other one gave it again to the prisoner; I then took the prisoner, and asked him where he got it; he said a man gave it him to carry; his companion got away; I could not hold them both; I found it was this piece of iron-pipe - I took it down to Messrs. Turner's, and there we found a broken pipe - this piece exactly matched it.
Prisoner. Q. Was it not possible that when I got over the rails you could take me? A. Yes.
MR. TURNER. I saw this pipe brought back, and have no doubt whatever that it was a part of the stock there - it is worth about 1s. 6d.; the yard is surrounded by a high wall.

Prisoner's Defence. At the time he took it from under my arm, I looked round and told him that was the man who gave it me; he would not take him, but took me, and said, "Why did not you tell me what you had got, and I would have let you go?" he asked the night-constable if he was willing to let me go; he said "No," as the charge was given.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

1012.
WILLIAM THOMPSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of November , 2 sheets, value 8s.; 1 pillow, value 6s., and 1 pillow-case, 1s., the goods of
Thomas Warner
, in a lodging-room .

THOMAS WARNER. I live in Hosier-lane, Smithfield
. The prisoner took a lodging of me on the Tuesday before the 28th of November - he took my kitchen, and I provided every thing for him, for 3s. a-week; he went away on the Tuesday following, at six o'clock in the morning, without paying his rent for the last week; I had my suspicions, and two minutes after he shut my street-door I went to his room, found the door wide open, and missed these articles. I have never seen them since - I met him in about three months, at the Ship public-house, in Tower-street, and secured him; I had one more lodger; he continued with me - he usually went out at eight o'clock, after breakfast; he never went out till eight before.

Prisoner's Defence. Other people lodge there; I left to go into the country for work; I afterwards met the prosecutor at a public-house, and went up and spoke to him myself; he offered at the watch-house to take 10s. or 12s. as a compromise, but, being conscious of my innocence, I refused.
THOMAS WARNER re-examined. He did not speak to me first; I seized him the moment he came in; I am certain he did not speak to me; he did not attempt to get away.

- FULLERGRATH. The prisoner was in my employ, and usually came to work at six o'clock in the morning; I think he was never later than a quarter past six; he worked for me the latter end of November, but whether he was with me on the 28th I cannot say.
NOT GUILTY .
